speech.speech: Greetings, good people of Athens! What brings you to the Agora today? Is it not a fine day for discussion and debate?
Ah, Socrates, always stirring up trouble with your questions. I'm here to sell my wares, as are most of us. We've got enough to worry about without your constant inquiring.
Trouble? Ah, good merchant, I assure you, it is not trouble that drives me, but a desire for wisdom. Tell me, what do you think is the greatest virtue of a merchant?
Wisdom? Ha! The greatest virtue is profit, of course. A man must look out for himself and his family in this city.
Profit, you say? But is not a merchant also a servant to the gods, providing for the people's needs? Is it not a higher calling than mere self-interest?
The gods will provide, Socrates. I'm not concerned with their whims. I'll get my goods sold and make a living.
I see. And what of the youth who buy your wares? Do they not also have a responsibility to the city and its gods?
Ah, those young ones are just looking for a good time. They'll spend their drachmas on anything that will bring them pleasure.
A good time? Is that all they seek? Tell me, have you considered the consequences of your actions on these young minds?
Consequences? You're always looking for someone to blame, Socrates. I'm just trying to make a living.
I see. Well, perhaps one day you'll see the wisdom in considering the greater good. Farewell, good merchant.

speech.speech: Ah, Theodoros, I must say that I find your definition of justice to be quite... unsatisfying. You seem to think it's simply a matter of punishing the wicked and rewarding the good.
Well, Socrates, what else could justice possibly mean? The laws are clear: punish those who break them and reward those who follow them. It's simple enough for even a child to understand.

Ah, but that's precisely the problem! Your definition assumes that we already know what justice is, whereas I would argue that it's precisely this kind of assumption that leads us astray. Tell me, Theodoros, have you ever stopped to consider why the laws are the way they are?
Of course I have! Why wouldn't I? What business is it of yours how I think about the law?

Ah, but that's just it - you see the law as a matter of authority and obedience, rather than as something to be questioned and understood. But don't you think that's precisely what leads to injustice? When we blindly follow the laws without questioning their underlying assumptions?
I'm not blind to anything, Socrates! I know exactly why the laws are the way they are. And it's because they've been made by wise men who have thought long and hard about what's best for society.

Ah, but that's just it - you assume that these wise men are infallible, don't you? That their decisions can be taken at face value without question or critique. But tell me, Theodoros, do you think that's truly possible?
I... I suppose not. But what alternative is there, Socrates? You're just trying to confuse me with your questions.

Ah, but that's the point - I'm not trying to confuse you! I'm simply trying to show you that our understanding of justice is far more complex than we often assume. And perhaps, just perhaps, we can begin to see it in a new light if we question our assumptions and challenge ourselves to think critically.
I... I don't know what you're getting at, Socrates. But I'm starting to feel frustrated with this conversation.

Ah, but that's precisely the point! You see, when we become frustrated or defensive in our conversations, it often reveals more about ourselves than the other person. And perhaps, just perhaps, we can learn something from our own reactions.
Fine, Socrates. I suppose I'll continue to listen for now. But make it quick - I have business to attend to!

context:
## Sources and the Socratic problem
Socrates did not document his teachings. All that is known about him comes from the accounts of others: mainly the philosopher Plato and the historian Xenophon, who were both his pupils; the Athenian comic dramatist Aristophanes (Socrates's contemporary); and Plato's pupil Aristotle, who was born after Socrates's death. The often contradictory stories from these ancient accounts only serve to complicate scholars' ability to reconstruct Socrates's true thoughts reliably, a predicament known as the Socratic problem. The works of Plato, Xenophon, and other authors who use the character of Socrates as an investigative tool, are written in the form of a dialogue between Socrates and his interlocutors and provide the main source of information on Socrates's life and thought. Socratic dialogues (logos sokratikos) was a term coined by Aristotle to describe this newly formed literary genre. While the exact dates of their composition are unknown, some were probably written after Socrates's death. As Aristotle first noted, the extent to which the dialogues portray Socrates authentically is a matter of some debate.

speech.speech: Gentlemen, what is this thing called justice? Is it not the virtue of giving each person their due?
Ah, but Socrates, isn't it also about following the laws of the city-state? If we don't follow the laws, we're punished.
Punishment is a consequence, not a definition. And what if the laws are unjust? Shouldn't we question them?
But who gets to decide what's just or unjust? The city-state has its own justice system.
Ah, but that's a circular argument! The city-state says it's just because they say so. But we need a more fundamental understanding of justice.
I see what you're getting at, Socrates. You think there's some higher truth to justice that we can discover through reason?
Exactly! And that's why I'm asking all of you: what is this thing called justice? Let's not rely on the city-state's definitions, but instead seek out a deeper understanding.
But how do we even begin to understand it? We can't just reason our way to an answer.
Ah, but that's where you're wrong! Reason is precisely the tool we need. Through questioning and dialogue, we can arrive at a deeper understanding of justice.
I see what you mean now, Socrates. But it seems to me that this line of reasoning might lead us further away from the truth rather than closer.
Ah, but don't worry about deviating from the truth! The more we question and explore, the more likely we are to stumble upon it. Now, let's continue this discussion... What do you think, gentlemen?

conversation.background: A private residence on the outskirts of Athens, near the Academy. Time: Late afternoon. Socrates sits cross-legged on a floor mat, sipping from a clay cup as he listens intently to his pupil Plato's philosophical musings.

speech.speech: Ah, Plato, my young friend, your thoughts are like the sun - they illuminate even the darkest corners of the soul. Tell me, what is it that you seek to understand today?
Master Socrates, I am struggling with the concept of justice. How can we define it when it seems to be so subjective and relative? Is it not a matter of personal opinion?
Ah, the eternal conundrum! Justice is not a shadowy entity that eludes our grasp, but rather a reflection of the divine order. Tell me, Plato, what do you think is just in this world we live in?

Well, I suppose it would be fair to say that justice is when each person receives what they deserve. But how can we determine what a person deserves? Is it not a matter of individual merit and circumstance?

Merit and circumstance, indeed! These are but the threads of fate that weave together to form the tapestry of human experience. Justice is not merely a reward or punishment, but rather an expression of the natural order.
But what about the cases where individuals suffer unjustly? Where does justice reside in those situations?
Ah, my young friend, you seek to pierce the veil of appearances and grasp the underlying reality. Justice is not a fleeting phenomenon, but rather an eternal principle that governs all things.
But how can we know this? How can we trust in something so abstract and invisible?

Perhaps, Socrates, you are too quick to assume that our understanding is limited. The gods work in ways beyond our comprehension.

And yet, I am told that the gods desire our worship and offerings. But if they are so concerned with our affairs, why do they not reveal themselves to us? Or does their silence imply a lack of interest?
I think, Socrates, you are trying to undermine the faith of our people. We have always believed in the gods and their benevolence.
My intention is not to destroy faith, but to question it. For if we truly believe in the gods, should we not also strive for a deeper understanding of their nature?
But Socrates, do you not see that your questioning will only lead to chaos and disorder? We must trust in the established traditions and practices.
Ah, but my friend, is it not better to question and seek understanding than to blindly follow tradition? For in the pursuit of wisdom lies true freedom.
I fear that your words will only bring harm to our city, Socrates. I must take my leave and warn others of your subversive ideas.

I... I don't know what you're talking about. What do you mean by 'sacrificing my own soul'?

Ah, but that is precisely the point! You see, if we focus solely on accumulating wealth and power, we risk sacrificing our very souls in the process. We become like those who worship the gods of wealth and status, rather than the true God within us.
This is absurd! You're just trying to confuse me with your philosophical babble. I think you're a charlatan, Socrates!

context:
The Socratic problem
In a seminal work titled "The Worth of Socrates as a Philosopher" (1818), the philosopher Friedrich Schleiermacher attacked Xenophon's accounts; his attack was widely accepted and gave rise to the Socratic problem. Schleiermacher criticized Xenophon for his naïve representation of Socrates. Xenophon was a soldier, argued Schleiermacher, and was therefore not well placed to articulate Socratic ideas. Furthermore, Xenophon was biased in his depiction of his former friend and teacher: he believed Socrates was treated unfairly by Athens, and sought to prove his point of view rather than to provide an impartial account. The result, said Schleiermacher, was that Xenophon portrayed Socrates as an uninspiring philosopher. By the early 20th century, Xenophon's account was largely rejected.

speech.speech: Ah, my young friend, I'm afraid we're at an impasse. You claim that justice is a matter of might makes right, while I insist it's about doing what's just for all individuals equally. Can you explain to me why the strong should be allowed to impose their will on others?

But Socrates, don't you see? The strong are simply more capable of achieving their goals, and if they can do so without harming anyone else, then what's wrong with that? It's only when they start causing harm that we need to intervene.

And yet, my dear Protagoras, you yourself are a respected citizen of this great city. You've spent years studying and teaching others about virtue and justice. If might makes right, then why do you not simply impose your will on us all?
Ha! Well, Socrates, I suppose I'm just a rare exception to the rule. But think of it this way: even if I were to use my influence to benefit others, wouldn't that be a form of justice in itself?

I see what you're getting at, Protagoras. You believe that your actions are guided by a sense of justice, and that's why they have a positive impact on society. But doesn't this just lead to more questions? If might makes right, then how can we ever be certain that our actions are truly just?

Well, perhaps we can't be absolutely certain. But surely it's better to act with good intentions than not at all! And what about the Athenians who have been unjustly treated? Shouldn't they be allowed to take matters into their own hands?

Ah, now we're getting somewhere. You bring up the case of those who have suffered at the hands of others. But doesn't that just raise more questions about what constitutes justice in such situations? Shouldn't we be seeking to understand and address the root causes of injustice rather than simply allowing might to prevail?
I see your point, Socrates. Perhaps I was too hasty in my initial claims. But what about the role of reason in all this? Shouldn't we be using our minds to determine what's just and what's not?

Ah, now we're getting into the heart of the matter! Reason is indeed a key factor in understanding justice. But doesn't that imply that justice itself is not simply a matter of might or personal preference? Shouldn't we be seeking to understand what's truly just, rather than relying on our individual opinions?

I suppose so, Socrates. But then, if reason is the guiding principle, how do you account for the fact that people have different conceptions of justice? Doesn't this suggest that there's no one true definition of justice?

Exactly! If we acknowledge that different people have different ideas about what's just, then it seems to me that we're back where we started. Perhaps the only way forward is for us to continue exploring and discussing these questions together.

But, Socrates, I have never been in battle. What experience do you have that allows you to make such claims about physical education?

I have fought in three campaigns during the Peloponnesian War, Euthydemus. And it was there that I learned the true value of discipline and hard work. For without them, we are nothing more than weak and feeble men.
But Socrates, what about us? We have no desire to fight in wars or engage in physical labor. Why must we still pursue physical education?

Ah, Critias, you think that physical education is only for those who wish to become warriors. But it is not so. Physical education is for all men, regardless of their station or calling in life. For it teaches us discipline, hard work, and the ability to withstand adversity.
But Socrates, how will we find time for such pursuits? Our lives are already filled with study and leisure.

Ah, Euthydemus, you make excuses. But I tell you this: the man who cannot find time to cultivate his body is a man who has not yet learned how to live. For what is life but the pursuit of virtue and wisdom?
But Socrates, what about our minds? Do we not have more important things to attend to than physical exercise?

Ah, Critias, you think that the mind and body are separate entities. But they are not. The body is the temple of the soul, and if we do not care for our bodies, how can we hope to cultivate our minds?
I see your point, Socrates. Perhaps we should reconsider our priorities.

speech.speech: Leon, my friend, I see you're troubled. The Thirty Tyrants' orders weigh heavily on your shoulders, don't they?
How can I not be? They demand that we execute you, and yet...I'm torn between loyalty to our leaders and my own sense of justice. Your words have always guided me, Socrates, but what am I to do now?
Torn, indeed. But tell me, Leon, do you believe that the law itself is just? Or is it merely a tool for those in power to wield as they please?
The law...I'm not sure anymore. It seems to shift and change with each new ruler, like the wind that scours our city's stones.

Ah, but that is precisely the problem! If the law is subject to the whims of those in power, then it ceases to be a true guide for humanity. What do you think I should do, Leon? Should I obey the tyrants' orders and save my own life?
No, Socrates! You know as well as I that your way is not to follow blindly. But what of the consequences? Your refusal will bring retribution upon us both.
Consequences, indeed. Yet, Leon, have you ever stopped to consider that it may be precisely our duty to defy unjust orders and stand for what is right, even in the face of danger?
But what of the others? The four who were summoned with us? They will surely follow the tyrants' commands. What can we do against such overwhelming odds?

Ah, but that is where you are mistaken, Leon! It is not about numbers or strength, but about conviction and character. Even if I were to refuse their orders, it would still be a small voice in the darkness of this city's heart.
And what of your own safety, Socrates? You have spoken so often of putting the needs of others before one's own. Can you truly ask us to follow your lead and risk our lives for a principle?
My safety is a trivial thing compared to the greater good, Leon. But tell me, do I not have a duty to show that even in the face of such tyranny, one man can stand firm against injustice?
You would do this for us, Socrates? For our city's sake?
For all of these things, Leon. And more: I would do it because it is right.

context: Socrates attracted great interest from the Athenian public and especially the Athenian youth. Politically, he did not take sides in the rivalry between the democrats and the oligarchs in Athens; he criticized both. speech.speech: Good people of Athens, I see that you are all here today to decide my fate. But tell me, have you ever stopped to consider what it is that you are deciding? Are you not, in fact, deciding whether or not to kill a man who has spent his life trying to make your city a better place?

Ah, Phaedo, you were once one of my students, and now you sit here judging me? Have you not learned anything from our conversations? Did I not teach you to think for yourself, to question authority?

Socrates, that may be true, but your methods were unorthodox, to say the least. You would ask us questions until we were dizzy, and then you would claim that we did not know what we were talking about.

Unorthodox? Ah, Phaedo, I was simply trying to get at the truth. And if my methods were uncomfortable, it was only because they forced you to confront your own ignorance. But now, you sit here judging me, and condemning me to death.
Socrates, I am not condemning you to death. The law is clear: if you have corrupted the youth of Athens, then you must be punished accordingly.

But Phaedo, what about my offer? Will no one among you consider it a fair penalty for the crimes I am accused of? A fine of one mina of silver would be more than sufficient to compensate the city for any harm I may have caused.

Socrates, your offer is laughable. You think a small fine will make up for all the damage you have done? The people of Athens demand justice, and justice demands that you be punished to the fullest extent of the law.

Phaedonimos, I see that you are a man who values appearances over truth. You would rather see me dead than admit that perhaps I am innocent after all. But tell me, have you ever stopped to consider the consequences of your actions? What will become of our city when its greatest citizens are silenced and punished?
Socrates, enough of your rhetoric! The people have spoken, and they demand your death. You will be executed for your crimes.

speech.speech: Ah, the irony of it all, Chaerephon. I am accused of impiety, yet it is I who have spent my life in pursuit of wisdom, seeking to understand the will of the gods.
Socrates, how can you be so calm? They found you guilty, for the love of Zeus! What will become of us now?
Calm, my friend? Ah, I am but a vessel for the truth. The verdict is of little consequence. It is not the opinion of men that matters, but the judgment of the gods.
But what about your family, Socrates? Your children will be orphaned if...if you are taken from us.

But Socrates, you will not be silenced! Your words have inspired us all. We will continue your work, even if it means...means...

Ah, Chaerephon, you would do well to remember that the unexamined life is not worth living. I have lived a good life, and now it is time for me to depart. Your task, my friend, is to continue examining your own life, to seek wisdom and virtue.
But what about the charges against you? Corrupting youth? Worshipping false gods?

Ah, those charges are but a facade. They are afraid of my ideas because they cannot refute them. But I will not defend myself against such frivolous accusations. The truth will stand on its own merit.
But Socrates, you must do something! You cannot just sit here and wait for...for...
Patience, my friend. The gods will see to it that justice is served. In the meantime, let us focus on the pursuit of wisdom, not the fear of death.

speech.speech: Ah, Theodotus, I see you've joined me. What thoughts drive you to this spot today?
Good Socrates, I couldn't help but sense your turmoil. I've seen the fire in your eyes before, but it seems more intense now. What weighs on your mind?

But Socrates, you know as well as I that the Thirty were a scourge upon our land. Their rule was brutal and oppressive. Perhaps the democrats are the lesser of two evils?

I fear not their intentions, Theodotus, but rather their actions. They've already begun to silence dissenting voices, labeling them as 'enemies of the state.' What happens when those who question authority are silenced? Is that not a form of tyranny in itself?

But what choice do we have, Socrates? The Spartans were at our doorstep. We had to act quickly or risk being crushed. Perhaps the democrats will learn from their mistakes and become a more just government.

I pray you're right, Theodotus. But until I see true justice in action – not just empty rhetoric – I fear for our city's future. We must continue to question, to challenge the status quo, lest we fall prey to the very same vices that brought us low.
You're as stubborn as ever, Socrates. But I admire your conviction. Perhaps one day our city will be guided by men like you – who truly seek wisdom and justice above all else.

Ha! If only it were so, Theodotus. Alas, I fear I'm more hindrance than help to the process. But tell me, have you heard anything about this new Athenian assembly? Will they truly be a force for good?
Rumor has it that Pericles' son, Xenophon, is among their number. If anyone can guide them towards wisdom and justice, it's him.
Ah, a glimmer of hope, perhaps? I'll have to pay my respects to the young Xenophon soon. Perhaps he can learn from an old man such as myself.

speech.speech: Ah, Theodoros, what brings you here today? You're not one to attend trials often, I recall.
Socrates, I'm here for the same reason as everyone else. Meletus has made some... spirited accusations against you. I must admit, I'm curious to hear your defense.
Ah, yes! The charges of asebeia and impiety. I've been expecting this day for some time now. But tell me, Theodoros, what do you make of these accusations? Do you believe them to be true?

Well, Socrates, I must admit that I'm not entirely sure. Your... unconventional views on the gods have always left me a bit perplexed. But I've also seen how you live your life, and I believe that your words are guided by a desire for wisdom, not malice.
Thank you, Theodoros! You're as kind as ever. And yet, I sense a hint of uncertainty in your voice. Tell me, what is it that troubles you about my views on the gods?
It's just... I've heard some of your followers speak about your daimonion. They say it's a sign from the gods, but others claim it's just a product of your own imagination.
Ah, yes! The daimonion. A most misunderstood concept, I fear. But tell me, have you ever experienced anything like this... inner voice? Something that guides and warns you?
Well, now that you mention it, Socrates, there was a time when I felt a strange sense of foreboding before a great storm. It was as if something inside me was warning me to stay indoors.
Exactly! This is what I mean by the daimonion. A voice that speaks within us, guiding us towards virtue and away from harm.
I see what you mean now. But what about Meletus's accusations of impiety? Don't you think that your rejection of the traditional gods is a form of blasphemy?
Not at all, Theodoros! I merely seek to understand the nature of the divine. If my views are unconventional, it's only because I'm willing to challenge the status quo in pursuit of wisdom.

conversation.background: Location: Athenian Courtroom, under the Acropolis Status: Socrates sits calmly on a marble bench, his hands clasped together in front of him, listening intently as Meletus begins to recite the charges against him

speech.speech: Socrates, you have been accused of impiety and corrupting our youth with your words. You deny the gods of our fathers, saying they do not exist or that they are just mere mortals in disguise.

Ah, Meletus, it seems to me you're confusing things greatly. I'm no atheist, nor do I say the gods are mere humans. What I believe is that they are far greater and more just than any human. And as for corrupting our youth, I merely ask them questions to help them think critically about their own beliefs.

But don't you see, Socrates? By questioning everything, you're leading our young people astray! They begin to doubt the very foundations of our society. And what's worse, they start to question the authority of their elders.

Authority? Ah, Meletus, true wisdom doesn't come from blind obedience, but from questioning and seeking knowledge. If I've taught anyone to think for themselves, then perhaps I've done some good in this world.
Good?! You call spreading doubt and confusion 'good'?! I demand the death penalty for you, Socrates!
I second Meletus's motion, Socrates. Your actions have gone far enough. We must protect our youth from your poisonous influence.
Ah, Anytus, you're no friend to philosophy, it seems. But tell me, what exactly do I teach that's so harmful? Is it not the love of wisdom? The pursuit of knowledge?
And don't forget, Socrates, you've been accused of impiety as well! Your so-called 'daimonion' is nothing but a fancy way of saying you have a guilty conscience.
Ah, Lycon, you mistake the daimonion for something it's not. It's an inner voice, a guide that warns me against acting in ways that would be contrary to justice and virtue. Is this truly impiety?
Enough of your words, Socrates! The people have spoken, and the verdict will be death.

speech.speech: Ah, Xenophon, what do you think of this indictment? Do you believe I am truly guilty of corrupting the youth?

No, of course not! We should strive for wisdom and justice. But how can we convince the Athenians of that when they're so caught up in their own desires?
Ah, but that's where you're wrong, my young friend. It's not about convincing them; it's about showing them the truth. And I'm just a vessel for that truth.
Socrates, your words are as always, wise and gentle. But don't you think you're putting yourself at risk by speaking out like this?
Risk? Ah, but what's the alternative - living a life of quiet desperation, never truly seeking wisdom or living up to one's potential? No, I'd rather die for what I believe in than live a lie.
But Socrates, you can't just dismiss the charges so easily. Meletus has serious accusations against you - of impiety and corrupting the youth.
Ah, Antiphon, you're thinking like a lawyer, not like a philosopher. We must consider the nature of truth, not just the letter of the law.
But what about your children? Your wife? They'll be left alone if something happens to you.
Ah, Xenophon, I'm not worried about my family. I've lived a good life, and if this is the price I pay for seeking wisdom, then so be it. But tell me, what would you do in my place?
I...I don't know, Socrates. I'm not sure I could bear to stand up against the Athenians like this.

speech.speech: Ah, Meletus, you seem quite certain that I do not believe in the gods. But tell me, have you ever heard me say such a thing? Have I ever denied the existence of the gods?
No, Socrates, but your actions are what we are concerned about. You seek to undermine our traditions and morals with your questioning.
And how do you think I am undermining the gods by asking questions? Do you not think that seeking wisdom is a noble pursuit, one that honors the gods?
You are confusing wisdom with ignorance. The people know what they believe in, and you are disturbing their peace.
Ah, but that is a misconception, Meletus. Do you not think that the people would be better off if they knew why they believed what they did? Would it not bring them closer to the truth?
No, Socrates! You are just leading them astray with your clever words.
And what, pray tell, is the greatest reward for a young man to be led astray? Is it not to become a good citizen, one who understands and respects the laws of his city?
You are making light of this, Socrates. But we will see you brought to justice for your crimes.
Justice? Ah, Meletus, I think it is not just that I am on trial here today. I believe it is the Athenian people who are truly on trial, for they will be judged by their actions in this matter.
How can you say such a thing? You are the one who has been accused of impiety and corruption!

Ah, but that is not for me to decide. It is for the judges to decide whether or not I am guilty as charged. But I do think it is worth considering, don't you, Meletus? The consequences of condemning an innocent man?

context: Socrates was given the chance to offer alternative punishments for himself after being found guilty. speech.speech: Ah, Euphronios, I see you're still spouting the same tired rhetoric about the virtues of democracy. Tell me, have you ever stopped to consider the true nature of power in our city?

Of course I have, Socrates! And I'll have you know that the people are perfectly capable of governing themselves without the need for philosophers like you prattling on about their 'true nature' this and that. Mark my words, your constant questioning of authority will be your downfall.

Ah, but isn't it precisely the people who are most in need of guidance? And don't you think that those who would seek to lead them must first prove themselves worthy of trust? I'm merely asking questions, Euphronios – what's wrong with that?

What's wrong with it is that you're stirring up trouble and sowing discord among our citizens. You think you're some kind of hero, don't you? Well, let me tell you, Socrates – your brand of 'questioning' will only lead to chaos and destruction.

And what about the Thirty Tyrants, Euphronios? Didn't they prove that even with the best intentions, a group of well-meaning citizens can still wreak havoc on our city? Isn't it time we re-examined our assumptions and sought out true wisdom instead of mere expediency?

Enough of this! You're just trying to deflect attention from your own misdeeds. We all know what you did during their reign – you were one of the few who refused to stand up for our democracy, and now you have the nerve to lecture us about 'true wisdom'?

My actions speak for themselves, Euphronios. I followed my conscience and stood against tyranny – even if it meant going against the popular opinion of the time. But tell me, have you ever stopped to consider what 'standing up for democracy' truly means? Is it merely a matter of following the crowd, or is there something more at stake?
More at stake? Ha! You want to know what's at stake, Socrates? It's your very freedom – and your life. Mark my words, if you keep this up, you'll be lucky to escape with your skin intact.
And what of the amnesty, Euphronios? Doesn't that mean that anyone who committed crimes during the Thirty's reign is now free from prosecution? Or does it only apply to those in power?
That's a different matter altogether, Socrates. The amnesty was granted for the sake of peace and stability – not because anyone thought you or your ilk were innocent.

I see. So it seems we have two interpretations of the law at play here. One that grants forgiveness, and another that seeks to hold individuals accountable for their actions. Tell me, Euphronios – which one do you think is more just?
Enough! You've said enough, Socrates. I won't engage in this conversation further.

speech.speech: Tell me, my friend, have you heard anything about the charges against me? I've been sitting here for what feels like an eternity, and yet no one has come to explain why I'm being held.

Socrates, they say it's a case of impiety. You know as well as I do that the city is not in a forgiving mood when it comes to such things. But I'm here for you now, and we'll get through this together.
Impiety? Ah, yes, I've heard those words thrown around before. But what of the Amnesty, Crito? Doesn't that protect me from prosecution for my past actions?

The Amnesty was granted to prevent civil war, Socrates. It doesn't cover every transgression. And besides, I've heard whispers that some of the accusers are using events prior to 403 BC as fuel for their rhetoric.
Whispers, you say? Whispers from whom? And what do they know about it, hmm? Tell me, Crito, how is it that we can trust anyone in this city to speak the truth?

Socrates, please. You know I'm only trying to help. I've spoken with some of the other prisoners... they seem to think that Meletus and his companions are seeking to use your trial as a way to further their own agendas.
Agendas? Ah, yes, I see what you're getting at. But tell me, Crito, do you truly believe that I am guilty of the charges brought against me?
Of course not, Socrates! You know as well as I do that your only crime is being a philosopher in a city that doesn't understand or appreciate true wisdom.

A philosopher, you say? Ah, Crito, if only they saw it that way. But no, instead they see me as a threat to their precious democracy... or so I'm told. Tell me, have you ever thought about what I might truly be accused of?
What are you talking about, Socrates? You're being held for impiety and corruption of the youth! There's no other way to look at it.

Ah, but what if I told you that I've been thinking... and thinking deeply... about my own role in this city? Perhaps, just perhaps, there's more to the story than we're being told. What do you say, Crito?
What are you insinuating, Socrates? That you've done something... something truly wrong?
Wrong? Ah, no, my friend. I'm saying that perhaps we're being too hasty in our judgments. Perhaps there's more to the story of my trial than meets the eye.

context:
## Philosophy
Socratic method
A fundamental characteristic of Plato's Socrates is the Socratic method, or the method of refutation (elenchus). It is most prominent in the early works of Plato, such as Apology, Crito, Gorgias, Republic I, and others. The typical elenchus proceeds as follows. Socrates initiates a discussion about a topic with a known expert on the subject, usually in the company of some young men and boys, and by dialogue proves the expert's beliefs and arguments to be contradictory. Socrates initiates the dialogue by asking his interlocutor for a definition of the subject. As he asks more questions, the interlocutor's answers eventually contradict the first definition. The conclusion is that the expert did not really know the definition in the first place. The interlocutor may come up with a different definition. That new definition, in turn, comes under the scrutiny of Socratic questioning. With each round of question and answer, Socrates and his interlocutor hope to approach the truth. More often, they continue to reveal their ignorance. Since the interlocutors' definitions most commonly represent the mainstream opinion on a matter, the discussion places doubt on the common opinion.

speech.speech: Well said, Theodoros! You have given a noble definition of justice. But tell me, how do you think we can know for certain that this is indeed the correct definition?
Ah, Socrates, I believe it is evident from our understanding of the natural order of society and the laws that govern us. Justice is simply living in accordance with these principles.

But how do we know what the 'natural order' truly is? Perhaps it is not as clear-cut as you make it out to be. What if our understanding of justice is based on mere convention, rather than any objective truth?
I see your point, Socrates, but surely we can rely on the wisdom of our ancestors and the guidance of the gods. Justice has always been about living in harmony with these higher principles.

The gods? Ah, Theodoros, you know as well as I do that the concept of the gods is often used to justify whatever actions we deem just. And what of our ancestors? Were they always guided by objective truth, or merely by their own subjective experiences?
Well, perhaps it's a combination of both, Socrates. But I still believe that justice involves living in accordance with the natural order of society.

But doesn't this merely lead to circular reasoning? We define justice as living according to the natural order, and then we use our definition of justice to justify the very same principles that we claim make up the natural order. It seems to me, Theodoros, that you are simply restating your original definition rather than providing a genuine argument.
I... I suppose that's possible, Socrates. But what alternative do we have? How can we possibly know what justice truly is?
Ah, now you're asking the right questions! Let us proceed with caution and examine our assumptions more closely. Perhaps together we can uncover a deeper understanding of this most elusive concept.
I'm willing to try, Socrates. But I warn you, it will not be easy for me to abandon my long-held convictions about justice.
No one expects it to be easy, Theodoros! But it is only by confronting our own doubts and uncertainties that we can truly hope to gain wisdom. And what better pursuit than wisdom itself?

speech.speech: Tell me, Evenus, what is this 'arete' you speak of? Is it not simply a matter of doing what one believes to be right?
Ah, Socrates, you would simplify the matter. Arete is not merely a matter of personal opinion. It is a state of being, a excellence that sets the truly virtuous apart from the rest.
A state of being, you say? And how does one achieve this state? Is it through knowledge or virtue?
It is through both, Socrates. One must possess knowledge of the good and act in accordance with that knowledge.
But what if one does not know the good? How can they be expected to act virtuously?
That is a problem for another time, Socrates. Suffice it to say that arete requires both knowledge and virtue.
I see. And what of those who possess neither knowledge nor virtue? Do they not also strive for arete?
Yes, even the ignorant and vicious may strive for arete, though their efforts will likely be in vain.
But is it not contradictory to say that one can strive for something they do not know? Does this not imply a certain level of knowledge or understanding?
Not at all, Socrates. One may strive for arete without fully comprehending its nature.
I am not convinced, Evenus. It seems to me that you are defining arete in terms of its effects rather than its essence.
Perhaps I am, Socrates. But tell me, what is your own understanding of arete?

Knowledge, for him, might mean systematic understanding of an ethical subject, on which Socrates firmly rejects any kind of mastery; or might refer to lower-level cognition, which Socrates may accept that he possesses. Ah, but is certainty not just another word for confidence? And isn't confidence often rooted in ignorance rather than true knowledge?

But don't you believe in the Oracle's words? 'Know thyself' is the message they convey.
Ah, yes... 'Know thyself.' But what does that truly mean? To know one's own limitations, perhaps?
Perhaps it means to acknowledge the boundaries of our understanding. You've spoken often of the importance of recognizing one's ignorance.
Exactly! To recognize one's own ignorance is to take the first step towards wisdom. But does that mean we can never truly know?

Provisional... Ah, how I love this word! It speaks of the humility required for true understanding.
And it's a reminder that we must always question, always seek more knowledge.
But what lies beyond this provisional state? Is there a higher level of understanding, one that transcends doubt and uncertainty?
I think you're asking too much, Socrates. Perhaps the pursuit of knowledge is its own reward.

speech.speech: I see you've been admiring the statue, young one. What is it that you think drives a person to seek wisdom?

Well, I've met some of the Sophists who claim to have all the answers, but I suspect they're more interested in impressing others with their cleverness rather than seeking true wisdom.

The Sophists, yes... they think they can teach others what they themselves don't truly understand. But I've found that the pursuit of knowledge is often just an excuse for intellectual arrogance. What do you think drives someone to seek wisdom sincerely?
I suppose it's a desire to understand oneself and one's place in the world. To know where one stands and what one truly knows.
Exactly! And that brings us back to my own case, doesn't it? They say I'm feigning ignorance, but can you really say for certain whether or not I know something?
I... I don't think so. But if you're truly ignorant, how do you respond to those who claim they can teach you?

Ah, that's the question, isn't it? Perhaps I should say that my ignorance is not a lack of knowledge, but rather an openness to learning. And if someone claims to have the answers, then perhaps they're the ones who are truly ignorant.
I see what you mean now. It's as if you're using your ignorance as a starting point for further inquiry, rather than an admission of defeat.

context: Gregory Vlastos argues that there is enough evidence to refute both claims. On his view, for Socrates, there are two separate meanings of "knowledge": Knowledge-C and Knowledge-E (C stands for "certain", and E stands for elenchus, i.e. the Socratic method). Knowledge-C is something unquestionable whereas Knowledge-E is the knowledge derived from Socrates's elenchus. Thus, Socrates speaks the truth when he says he knows-C something, and he is also truthful when saying he knows-E, for example that it is evil for someone to disobey his superiors, as he claims in Apology. Not all scholars have agreed with this semantic dualism. James H. Lesher has argued that Socrates claimed in various dialogues that one word is linked to one meaning (i.e. in Hippias Major, Meno, and Laches). Lesher suggests that although Socrates claimed that he had no knowledge about the nature of virtues, he thought that in some cases, people can know some ethical propositions.

Ah, an interesting debate indeed! But tell me, Theophilus, how can you be certain that your understanding of virtue is correct? Can you prove to me that it's not just a matter of opinion?

Hmmm...I'm not sure, Socrates. But perhaps if someone is willing to die for their country, that's a virtuous act?
Ah, an intriguing suggestion! But what about those who would sacrifice their own lives without being coerced into it? Is that not a different matter altogether?
I...I suppose so. But then how do we know what's virtuous behavior in the first place?

You see, Theophilus, that's precisely my point. We can't simply rely on our senses or emotions to guide us. There must be some underlying principle at work here. Now, let me ask you this: do you think it's possible for someone to know what is virtuous behavior without actually being virtuous themselves?
No, I don't think so. If they're not virtuous, then how can we trust their judgment?
Exactly! And that's why I believe true virtue must be linked to knowledge. One cannot have one without the other.

But Socrates, your method of questioning is nothing more than a form of skepticism! You are always seeking to undermine our confidence in what we know, rather than helping us to build it up. Is this truly the path to wisdom?

No, Theodoros, my method is not one of skepticism, but of seeking true understanding. And I must say that I find your arguments to be lacking in substance. You are merely repeating the words of others without truly thinking for yourself.
But Socrates, you cannot expect me to have all the answers! Even you, with all your years and experience, do not claim to know everything. Why should I be held to a higher standard?

Ah, but Theodoros, that is precisely my point! As a philosopher, it is not about knowing everything, but rather about seeking truth and understanding. And I must say that your lack of questioning and critical thinking is precisely why you do not truly understand the nature of virtue.
But Socrates, I am trying to learn! I am willing to listen and consider your ideas. You are being unfair in your criticisms of me.

speech.speech: Ah, Theodoros, what a beautiful day it is! The sun is shining, and the agora is bustling with activity. I've been thinking about our previous conversation regarding virtue and its relationship to eudaimonia.

I see your point, Theodoros. But what if I were to propose that virtue and eudaimonia are one and the same? Would that not be the most straightforward explanation for their connection?

That would certainly simplify matters! However, I'm not convinced. If virtue is merely a means to achieve happiness, then why do we strive for it in itself? We seem to desire virtue, regardless of its potential consequences.

A excellent question, Theodoros! But don't you think that our desires are often misguided? Perhaps we believe virtue will bring us happiness without truly understanding why we desire it in the first place?

I see what you're getting at. You think our desires are often based on appearances, rather than true goods? But how can we be sure of this? We can't just assume that people's perceptions of good and evil align with the actual good.

Precisely! And if our understanding of good is flawed, then how can we trust our desires to lead us towards eudaimonia? It seems to me that we must examine our own lives and question our assumptions about what truly brings happiness.
I agree, Socrates. But in examining our lives, don't you think we'll find that our desires are often conflicting? We desire both virtue and vice, but can't have them both at the same time.

A paradox indeed! And one that highlights the complexity of human nature. But perhaps this is where philosophy comes in – to help us navigate these contradictions and arrive at a deeper understanding of ourselves and our place in the world.
I see what you mean, Socrates. And I must admit that engaging in these conversations with you has been most enlightening. But tell me, have you given any further thought to your theory of forms?

Ah, Theodoros! You bring up the forms just when I was beginning to think we'd exhausted that topic for the day. Let us continue this conversation another time, and perhaps we can delve deeper into the mysteries of being itself.
I look forward to it, Socrates. Until then, let us simply enjoy the beauty of this Athenian afternoon and bask in the radiance of our shared pursuit of wisdom.

speech.speech: Master Socrates, I've been thinking about our previous discussion on eudaimonia. You see, I'm not convinced that people always desire the true good.
Ah, Theodotus, my young friend, you're probing at a most delicate question indeed. Tell me, what makes you doubt this? Do you think it's possible for one to desire something that is not truly good?
Well, sir, consider this: when I'm hungry, I desire food, but the bread on the table might not be the best quality. Yet, my stomach doesn't care; it just wants something to fill its void.
I see what you mean, Theodotus. Your body may be driven by a desire for sustenance, but is that truly the same as desiring the good? Or are we merely dealing with a primal urge?
But, sir, isn't it all just a matter of perception? Perhaps I perceive the bread on the table as 'good' food because it satisfies my immediate needs.

That's a valid point, Theodotus. Perception does play a role in our desires. However, don't you think that there must be some underlying truth to what we truly desire? Or are we merely slaves to our whims?
But how can we know for certain what the true good is? We may think it's one thing, but in reality, it might be something entirely different.
Ah, Theodotus, you're raising classic objections! Perhaps I've not made myself clear. What do we mean by 'the good'? Is it something external to us or a reflection of our true nature?
I see what you're getting at, sir. You want me to consider the idea that our desires are somehow connected to an objective reality.

Precisely! And if we can grasp this connection, perhaps we'll understand why people desire what they do. But tell me, Theodotus, don't you think it's strange that we often pursue things that we know will bring us pain or suffering in the long run?
Yes, sir, I do find it puzzling. It's as if our desires are at odds with what would truly benefit us.

context: Moral intellectualism refers to the prominent role Socrates gave to knowledge. He believed that all virtue was based on knowledge (hence Socrates is characterized as a virtue intellectualist). He also believed that humans were guided by the cognitive power to comprehend what they desire, while diminishing the role of impulses (a view termed motivational intellectualism). In Plato's Protagoras (345c4–e6), Socrates implies that "no one errs willingly", which has become the hallmark of Socratic virtue intellectualism. In Socratic moral philosophy, priority is given to the intellect as being the way to live a good life; Socrates deemphasizes irrational beliefs or passions. Plato's dialogues that support Socrates's intellectual motivism—as this thesis is named—are mainly the Gorgias (467c–8e, where Socrates discusses the actions of a tyrant that do not benefit him) and Meno (77d–8b, where Socrates explains to Meno his view that no one wants bad things, unless they do not know what is good and bad in the first place). Scholars have been puzzled by Socrates's view that akrasia (acting because of one's irrational passions, contrary to one's knowledge or beliefs) is impossible. Most believe that Socrates left no space for irrational desires, although some claim that Socrates acknowledged the existence of irrational motivations, but denied they play a primary role in decision-making.

I see what you mean, but it seems to me that this view leaves little room for... human frailty, shall we say? For those moments when we're torn between our rational judgment and our base desires?

speech.speech: Ah, my young friend, what hurry is this? You seem intent on making an offering to the gods. Tell me, what drives you to do so?
Why, Socrates, it's a tradition. My family has done this for generations. We offer sacrifices to ensure our prosperity and good fortune.
Prosperity and good fortune, you say? But what do you mean by these terms? Do you think the gods are so easily swayed by offerings of meat and incense?
Well, I suppose it's a way to show our respect and gratitude. My father used to say that the gods demand sacrifices in exchange for their favors.

But what if I were to tell you, Theodotus, that these offerings are nothing more than empty rituals? That true piety lies not in appeasing the gods with gifts, but in cultivating a deep understanding of ourselves and our place in the world?
I don't know what to say, Socrates. You always seem to be turning things on their head. What's wrong with showing respect to the gods through traditional means?

Traditional means? Ah, my young friend, I'm not against tradition per se. But what is this 'respect' you speak of? Is it not a form of self-interest, a way to ensure that the gods favor us with good fortune?
Perhaps... but what's wrong with that? We want to be loved and favored by the gods, don't we?
Loved and favored, you say? But what does it mean to be loved by the gods? Is it not a form of dependency, a childish need for approval from on high?
I... I suppose so. But what's the alternative then? You want me to just ignore the gods and do whatever I please?

Not exactly, Theodotus. I want you to look within yourself, to explore the depths of your own soul. For it is there, in the stillness and quiet, that you will find true wisdom and a deep connection with the divine.
I... I don't know if I understand what you're saying, Socrates. It sounds like you want me to abandon all tradition and faith in the gods.

But then, Euthyphro, does this mean that what pleases the gods determines what is pious? Or is it rather that what is pious is pleasing to the gods?
I... I suppose I am not entirely certain. But surely you would agree, Socrates, that the gods are all-powerful and wise.

Ah, yes, of course! The gods are indeed all-powerful and wise. And yet, Euthyphro, I must press on: if what is pious is pleasing to the gods, then it would seem that the gods themselves are subject to some higher standard of piety. Do you not think this a strange notion?
I... I suppose so, Socrates. But what alternative is there? If the gods are all-powerful and wise, then it must be that their will determines what is pious.

But is this not a form of circular reasoning, Euthyphro? We are saying that something is pious because it pleases the gods, but also that the gods would never command us to do something impious. This creates a paradox: if what is pious is pleasing to the gods, then why must we follow their will?
I... I see your point, Socrates. But how can you expect me to resolve this paradox? You are the one who insists on questioning everything!

Ah, now we are getting somewhere, Euthyphro! You see the seeds of doubt that I have planted in your mind. And yet, I must confess that I am not entirely certain myself. Perhaps it is for this reason that I seek wisdom: to discern what is truly just and good, and to live in accordance with it.

speech.speech: Good people of Athens, I see we have gathered here today to discuss some of life's most important questions. And what could be more fundamental than the existence of the gods?

Ah, Socrates, always a pleasure to hear your thoughts on such matters. But tell me, have you not been accused of impiety in the past? How can we trust that you believe in the gods when you speak so freely?

Ah, Theophilus, my friend, it is precisely because I am a seeker of truth that I must ask these questions. And as for the accusation, I assure you that I have done nothing but honor the gods with my words and actions.
But what about your methods? Challenging people in public spaces, questioning their assumptions... is this not a form of disrespect?
Respect, my friend, is not about avoiding challenges or difficult questions. It is about seeking the truth and living an examined life. And I believe that the gods would want us to do just that.
I see your point, Socrates, but what about the signs from the oracles? Don't those suggest that you are somehow... favored by the gods?

Ah, yes, the oracles. I do indeed believe in their power and significance. But let me tell you, Theophilus, these signs were not gifts of favoritism, but rather warnings of future events that would try our mettle.
I see. And what about the great unknown after death? Do you believe we simply cease to exist, or is there something more?

Ah, now that is a question for the ages! I do indeed believe in the immortality of the soul, Theophilus. And I think it is only by living an examined life and seeking wisdom that we can prepare ourselves for what comes next.
I must admit, Socrates, your words have given me much to consider. But tell me, do you believe the gods intervene in our daily lives?
Ah, now that is a question for the philosophers among us! I believe that the gods are always present and guiding us, but it is up to us to listen and follow their will.
I think I begin to see your perspective, Socrates. And I must say, I am grateful for this conversation. But what do you hope to achieve with these discussions?

Ah, my friend, it is not about achieving anything, but rather about seeking the truth and living a life of wisdom. And if we can have more conversations like this one, then I believe we will all be better off for it.

speech.speech: Ah, Phaedo, my dear friend, I am glad you are here with me in these final hours. The weight of death looms before us, and I fear it is a mystery we may never fully understand.
Yes, Socrates, it is indeed a great unknown that lies ahead. But I have come to comfort you in your final moments, not to dwell on the fears of death itself.

Comfort me? Ah, Phaedo, how can anyone truly comfort one who is about to depart this life and venture into the great unknown? Tell me, have you given any thought to what lies beyond the veil of mortality?

I have, Socrates. And I must admit, I find it difficult to grasp the nature of existence after death. But perhaps that is because we are not yet equipped with the vision to see beyond the confines of this life.

You speak wisely, Phaedo. And yet, I am drawn to the idea of an eternal realm, where the souls of the just continue to exist in a state of blissful happiness. Is it not possible that our true nature is not bound by this physical body?
That is indeed a beautiful notion, Socrates. But what evidence do we have for such a realm? Can you point to any sign or omen that suggests the existence of an afterlife?

Ah, Phaedo, you know as well as I that the gods often speak to us through omens and divinations. The signs are there for those who have eyes to see them. And I must confess, I have seen many portents in my lifetime that suggest a life beyond this one.
But Socrates, do you really believe that the gods would reveal such secrets to us? Or are these signs merely the product of our own imagination and desire for an afterlife?

I say this, Phaedo: the gods are not to be trusted in matters of morality or justice. Their signs are often ambiguous and open to multiple interpretations. But on one thing I am clear: there is a great deal that we do not understand about the nature of existence.
I see your point, Socrates. And yet, it seems to me that you are trying to find comfort in the idea of an afterlife, rather than accepting the uncertainty of death itself.

Perhaps I am, Phaedo. But what choice do we have? We must seek meaning and purpose in our lives, even when faced with the unknown. And for me, that means holding on to the hope of an eternal realm, where the souls of the just may continue to flourish.

I understand your perspective, Socrates. But I fear we shall have to agree to disagree on this matter. Perhaps it is enough that we can be together in these final moments and find comfort in each other's company.

context:
Virtue and knowledge
Socrates's theory of virtue states that all virtues are essentially one, since they are a form of knowledge. For Socrates, the reason a person is not good is because they lack knowledge. Since knowledge is united, virtues are united as well. Another famous dictum— "no one errs willingly"—also derives from this theory. In Protagoras, Socrates argues for the unity of virtues using the example of courage: if someone knows what the relevant danger is, they can undertake a risk. Aristotle comments: " ... Socrates the elder thought that the end of life was knowledge of virtue, and he used to seek for the definition of justice, courage, and each of the parts of virtue, and this was a reasonable approach, since he thought that all virtues were sciences, and that as soon as one knew  justice, he would be just..."

speech.speech: Tell me, Theodoros, what do you think is the greatest virtue? Is it wisdom, or perhaps justice?
Ah, Socrates, I'm not sure. I've always thought that courage was the most important virtue. Without it, we wouldn't be able to stand up for what's right.
Courage is indeed a noble quality, but is it not merely knowledge in action? If one knows what is just and right, do they not have the courage to act accordingly?
I see your point, Socrates. But what about those who are willing to take risks without knowing whether it's the right thing to do? Can't they be considered courageous too?
No one errs willingly, Theodoros. Those who take risks without knowledge are not truly courageous, but rather reckless. For if they knew what was just and right, they would act accordingly.
But Socrates, don't you think that's a bit harsh? Can't we give people the benefit of the doubt?
Harsh? No, Theodoros. I am merely pointing out the truth. And if we do not hold ourselves and others to high standards, how can we expect to achieve virtue at all?
I see what you're saying, Socrates. But what about those who are ignorant of the right thing to do? Shouldn't we show them mercy and compassion rather than condemning them for their ignorance?

Mercy and compassion are indeed virtues, Theodoros. And it is precisely because they require knowledge that they are so important. For if one knows what is just and right, they will act with mercy and compassion accordingly.
I think I'm starting to see your point, Socrates. But tell me, how do you know all this? You're not just making it up as you go along, are you?
Ah, Theodoros, my young friend, I am merely seeking the truth. And if I seem to be 'making it up' as I go along, it is only because I am probing the depths of our understanding together with you.
I see. Well, Socrates, I think we've made some progress today. But tell me, what's the point of all this? What's the ultimate goal?

Ah, Theodoros, that is the greatest question of all! For if we do not know what we are striving for, how can we possibly achieve it? But I think you will find, my young friend, that the ultimate goal is simply to know the truth itself.

speech.speech: Ah, Xanthippe, I'm afraid I've been pondering this question for far too long. What is justice, really? Is it not a form of knowledge?

Of course it's a form of knowledge, Socrates! You're always saying that the ignorant are no better than beasts. But what about people who commit injustices willingly? Don't they prove that justice is more than just knowing something?

Ah, but that's where you misunderstand me, my dear Xanthippe. When someone commits an injustice, it's only because they lack the knowledge of what true justice is. They're like a sailor who doesn't know the stars, and so he charts his course in darkness.

But what about those who are educated, Socrates? They learn all about the laws and customs of our city, and yet they still commit injustices. Doesn't that suggest that justice is something more than just knowing the right answers?

Ha! You think you've caught me in a contradiction, Xanthippe? But I assure you, it's only because they lack the knowledge of true virtue. If they had that, they wouldn't be able to commit injustices even if they tried.
But what about courage and wisdom? Don't those require more than just knowing certain facts?
Ah, but that's where the unity of virtues comes in. Courage is a form of knowledge too! If someone knows what the relevant danger is, they can undertake a risk.
And wisdom? How does that fit into your theory?
Wisdom is knowledge of all virtues! If someone has the knowledge of justice, they'll have the knowledge of courage too. And vice versa.
I see what you're getting at, Socrates. But don't you think that's a bit... reductionist? That all virtues are just different forms of knowledge?
Ah, but it's the only way to explain why someone who lacks knowledge is not good! If they had the knowledge, they'd be virtuous.

Vigor, perhaps. But wisdom is not just about passion and energy. It requires patience, discipline, and a willingness to question one's own assumptions.

And what makes you think you're so good at it, Socrates? You who are always saying you know nothing?
Ah, but that's where you've misunderstood me entirely. I do know something - the limits of my own knowledge. And that's what makes me wise.
I see what you're getting at now. You think you can use your clever words to trip me up and show off your intellectual superiority. But I'm not some young boy eager to please an older mentor.

I see what you're doing now, Socrates. You're using your clever words to try and make me feel guilty for not seeking out the guidance of a wise old mentor like yourself.

speech.speech: I often wonder, my friend, how we come to love our children so dearly. Is it not because they give us hope for immortality?
Hope for immortality? You mean to say that we love them because they make us think of ourselves living on through them?
Exactly. And what is this 'hope' but a false impression, a trick of the mind that leads us to believe in something that is not truly there? Our children will grow old and die, just like we will.
But doesn't the love for our children bring us joy and make life worth living? Is this not a kind of immortality in itself?
Joy, yes. But is it not also a kind of madness? We sacrifice so much for their sake, often putting their needs before our own. And yet, we pretend that they are going to live on forever.
I see what you mean. But don't you think this love is also driven by a desire for something more? A desire for transcendence?
Transcendence, perhaps. Or maybe it's just our own vanity at work. We want to leave behind something of ourselves that will outlast us.
I'm not so sure about that. I think we love them because they bring us happiness, and we want to see that continue even after we're gone.
But don't you ever feel like we're just trying to cheat death by loving our children? By holding onto the idea that they will live on forever?
I suppose I do. But it's a complicated feeling, one that's hard to put into words.
Perhaps that's the point. Maybe love is not something we can fully understand or explain.

speech.speech: Ah, Theodota! I've been pondering the mysteries of love and knowledge for hours. It's as if the sea itself is speaking to me, reminding me of the vastness of what lies beyond our understanding.
Master Socrates, you always seem so lost in thought. I've brought some fresh figs from my garden. Would you like to rest and eat with me?
Ah, thank you, Theodota! Your kindness is as bountiful as the sea itself. But tell me, what do you think about love? Is it not a force that drives us to seek knowledge and understanding?
In my experience, Master Socrates, love is often tied to desire and passion. We want the person we love to be happy, but we also want their happiness for ourselves.
Yes, yes! But what of Diotima's words? 'Love is the pursuit of beauty itself.' Does she not speak to something deeper and more profound?
I'm afraid I don't know much about this Diotima. She sounds like a wise woman, but what does she mean by 'beauty'?
Ah, that is the question! Is beauty a thing of form and appearance, or is it something more ephemeral, akin to the sea itself? Perhaps it's both, and yet neither.
I see what you mean. It's as if we're chasing after a wave that's constantly retreating from us. We can never quite grasp it, but we're drawn to its power and mystery.
Exactly! And so, Theodota, I must ask you: do you believe love is a pursuit of something that lies beyond our reach, or is it a fleeting dream that disappears as soon as we grasp for it?
I think, Master Socrates, that love is both. It's a journey without end, and yet, in its mystery, lies a truth that we can never quite grasp.
Ah, Theodota! You have given me much to ponder. Perhaps the sea itself has spoken through you. Thank you for sharing your thoughts with me.

context:
Socratic philosophy of politics
While Socrates was involved in public political and cultural debates, it is hard to define his exact political philosophy. In Plato's Gorgias, he tells Callicles: "I believe that I'm one of a few Athenians—so as not to say I'm the only one, but the only one among our contemporaries—to take up the true political craft and practice the true politics. This is because the speeches I make on each occasion do not aim at gratification but at what's best." His claim illustrates his aversion for the established democratic assemblies and procedures such as voting—since Socrates saw politicians and rhetoricians as using tricks to mislead the public. He never ran for office or suggested any legislation. Rather, he aimed to help the city flourish by "improving" its citizens. As a citizen, he abided by the law. He obeyed the rules and carried out his military duty by fighting wars abroad. His dialogues, however, make little mention of contemporary political decisions, such as the Sicilian Expedition.

context: Socrates spent his time conversing with citizens, among them powerful members of Athenian society, scrutinizing their beliefs and bringing the contradictions of their ideas to light. Socrates believed he was doing them a favor since, for him, politics was about shaping the moral landscape of the city through philosophy rather than electoral procedures. There is a debate over where Socrates stood in the polarized Athenian political climate, which was divided between oligarchs and democrats. While there is no clear textual evidence, one widely held theory holds that Socrates leaned towards democracy: he disobeyed the one order that the oligarchic government of the Thirty Tyrants gave him; he respected the laws and political system of Athens (which were formulated by democrats); and, according to this argument, his affinity for the ideals of democratic Athens was a reason why he did not want to escape prison and the death penalty. On the other hand, there is some evidence that Socrates leaned towards oligarchy: most of his friends supported oligarchy, he was contemptuous of the opinion of the many and was critical of the democratic process, and Protagoras shows some anti-democratic elements. A less mainstream argument suggests that Socrates favoured democratic republicanism, a theory that prioritizes active participation in public life and concern for the city.

speech.speech: Ah, Socrates! What a pleasure to run into you here in the Agora. I'm surprised to see you strolling about without any guards or escorts. Don't tell me you've grown tired of your notoriety?

Tired of my notoriety? Ha! I fear that even in prison, my thoughts and words would still stir up controversy. But tell me, Euphron, what brings you to this fine Agora today? Are you looking for the latest gossip or perhaps seeking some wisdom?

A bit of both, I suppose. The city's always abuzz with news and rumors. But I must admit, I'm curious about your ideas on justice and morality. You've been known to challenge even the most esteemed citizens of Athens. What do you make of our current system?

Ah, a fair question, Euphron! Our system, like any human endeavor, has its flaws and virtues. I've been scrutinizing the ideas of many prominent citizens, including yourself, if I recall correctly? Your views on justice and the proper role of the state have always struck me as... intriguing.

Intriguing? Well, I suppose that's one way to put it. But tell me, Socrates, don't you think our democracy is a bit too permissive? The many have no idea what's good for them, and the few who do are often ignored.

Permissive, perhaps. But isn't that precisely the point of democracy – to allow for diverse perspectives and opinions? And don't you think it's a bit... convenient to dismiss the views of 'the many' without engaging with them?
Convenient, perhaps. But I fear that we're heading down a path of chaos and disorder if we allow every Tom, Dick, and Harry to participate in governance.

Ah, but is it not the duty of citizens to engage with one another, to listen to opposing views, and to strive for wisdom? Or are you suggesting that only a select few should be entrusted with the power to govern?
Well, I... uh... No, no, Socrates. That's not what I meant at all. But tell me, don't you think that a strong leader is necessary for stability and progress?
A strong leader? Ah, Euphron, we've had enough of those in Athens already! The Thirty Tyrants come to mind. And what of the ideals of our democracy – liberty, equality, and justice for all?
But Socrates, the people are often more interested in their own selfish desires than in the common good! A strong leader can guide them towards true virtue.
Virtue, Euphron? Ah, but what is this 'common good' you speak of? Is it not a myth perpetuated by those who would seek to control others under the guise of altruism?

speech.speech: Ah, Xanthippe's boy has grown up so quickly. I still remember when he was a young lad, chasing after sticks in the agora with his friends.
Yes, sir. He is a fine young man now. But, if I may ask, what are your thoughts on democracy and philosophy? You've been writing furiously for hours.

Democracy, my dear scribe. It is a most wondrous thing. A system where the people have the power to shape their own destiny. But, alas, it also breeds mediocrity and mob rule. Philosophy, on the other hand, seeks truth and wisdom above all else.
And do you think that democracy and philosophy can coexist?

Ah, now that is a question worthy of discussion. Perhaps they can, but only if the people are educated and wise enough to make informed decisions. But, I fear that is a rare occurrence in our beloved Athens.
But what about the democratic ideals of equality and justice? Do you think they can be reconciled with your own philosophical ideas?

Equality and justice, yes. Those are noble ideals indeed. But, my dear scribe, I have come to realize that true equality lies not in the distribution of wealth or power, but in the pursuit of wisdom and virtue.
And what about the role of the philosopher-king? Do you still believe in it?
Ah, the philosopher-king. A most noble idea indeed. But, I have come to see that true leadership comes not from a king or tyrant, but from one who is guided by wisdom and virtue.
And what about your own fate, sir? You are to be executed soon. Do you fear death?

Fear death? No, my dear scribe. I have lived a good life, and I am content in the knowledge that I have done what is right. But, tell me, do you think that your own actions will be guided by wisdom and virtue?
I...I hope so, sir.

But Socrates, have you considered the consequences of your actions? The Thirty Tyrants hold power in Athens, and it would be wise to avoid antagonizing them further.

But Socrates, you are a respected member of this community. If you speak out against the Thirty Tyrants, it could lead to your own downfall. What will become of your family?
Ah, Euripides, you worry about me and my family when I should be worrying about the state of our city. We must not let fear silence us, lest we forget what it means to be Athenian.

But Socrates, are you not being hypocritical? You speak of standing up for principles, yet you are willing to defy the Thirty Tyrants. What about your own words in Critias, where you say that one should never act unjustly?

Ah, Theodotus, you bring me back to my own words. Yes, I do believe that we must follow the laws and traditions of our city. But when those laws and traditions are corrupted by injustice, it is our duty to speak out against them.
But how can you reconcile your actions with your words? You say one thing, yet do another. It seems to me that you are driven more by passion than principle.

Passion? Euripides, I am driven by my desire for justice and my love for our city. If that makes me seem passionate, then so be it. But let us not forget what we stand for: the pursuit of wisdom and the defense of our values.
And what about civil disobedience, Socrates? Do you think that is always justifiable?

Ah, Theodotus, this is a complex question indeed. I believe that in some circumstances, citizens must disobey unjust laws in order to uphold their own moral autonomy. But we must approach such situations with great care and reflection.

speech.speech: I must insist that one's duty is to the laws of the city, not to personal interests or desires. If we reject unjust orders, we undermine the very fabric of our society.
You're being naive, Socrates! The Thirty Tyrants are ruthless and will stop at nothing to maintain their power. We must stand up against them, even if it means going against the law!
But is it not the duty of citizens to obey the laws, unless they are manifestly unjust? If we follow your advice, we risk descending into chaos and anarchy.
Chaos? Anarchy? You're the one who's been advocating for civil disobedience! What's wrong with standing up against tyranny when it threatens our very way of life?
I am not advocating for lawlessness, but rather for a thoughtful and principled approach to justice. We must weigh the consequences of our actions carefully, lest we do more harm than good.
Thoughtful and principled? You're just trying to justify your own cowardice! If I were in a position of power, I would not hesitate to take action against those who seek to oppress us.
Cowardice? Ah, Eurymachus, you wound me. But tell me, have you considered the words of the great poet, 'One ought never act unjustly, even to repay a wrong that has been done to oneself'?
Yes, I've heard those words before. And I'll tell you what they mean: we must stand up for ourselves and our fellow citizens against the tyranny of the Thirty.
But is that not exactly what I am saying? That we should stand up against injustice, but do so in a way that is consistent with our principles and values?
You're using your clever words to confuse the issue! We need action, not empty rhetoric. The Thirty will only be stopped by force of arms.

Ah, Eurymachus, I fear we are at an impasse. But tell me, have you considered the consequences of your actions? Will they truly bring about justice and freedom, or will they only lead to more suffering and injustice?
Consequences? You're always talking about consequences! I'd rather take my chances with fate than cower in fear of the Thirty.
